title: 111_hr2076
content: The "Border Security and Responsibility Act 2009" aims to protect Federal lands along the US-Mexico border from unauthorized immigration, smuggling, and border enforcement activities while ensuring border security operations are carried out. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms such as "Indian tribe," "Secretary," and "Secretary Concerned." SEC. 4. BORDER PROTECTION STRATEGY. This section outlines the border protection strategy as part of the Border Security and Responsibility Act 2009. The Border Protection Strategy, developed in consultation with various officials, aims to assess operational control levels through different security measures like fencing, barriers, and additional Border Patrol agents by September 30, 2009. The Border Protection Strategy includes measures such as pedestrian fencing, vehicle barriers near roads, additional Border Patrol agents, natural barriers, advanced technology like unmanned aerial vehicles, and regional variations in border security methodologies. The Border Protection Strategy includes analysis of difficult terrain and adverse environmental conditions, regional variations in border security methodologies, cooperation with Mexico and Canada, and removal of obstructive vegetation. Cost and impacts of security measures are also assessed, including land acquisition costs. The impacts of security measures assessed include land acquisition, construction, maintenance, contractor, management, wildlife, habitat, natural communities, cross-border wildlife migration corridors, hydrology, and costs of mitigating adverse impacts on various lands and waters. The curr_chunk discusses the costs of mitigating adverse impacts on various lands, waters, wildlife habitats, and residents near the border. It also includes considerations for wildlife migration corridors and impacts on culture, safety, and quality of life. The curr_chunk focuses on the fiscal investments in acquiring or managing lands and waters near the US border for conservation purposes, including wildlife migration corridors in various federal, tribal, state, local, and private areas. The curr_chunk discusses recommendations for strategic border security management based on comparative security, cost-benefit analysis, and protection of investments in public lands. The curr_chunk outlines required training for Customs and Border Protection agents and other Federal personnel involved in border security infrastructure and patrol operations. The training for Customs and Border Protection agents and other Federal personnel involved in border security infrastructure and patrol operations must be appropriate to the mission of the relevant agency and focused on achieving border security objectives while minimizing adverse impacts on natural and cultural resources. SEC. 5. ACTIONS TO GAIN OPERATIONAL CONTROL OF THE INTERNATIONAL LAND BORDERS OF THE UNITED STATES. Amendment to improve operational control of the border. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to gain operational control of the international land borders of the United States in accordance with the border protection strategy. Priority should be given to using remote cameras, sensors, natural barriers, manpower, unmanned aerial vehicles, and other low impact border enforcement techniques. Consultation with various government agencies and stakeholders is necessary to minimize the impact on the environment, culture, commerce, safety, and quality of life for communities. The Secretary of Homeland Security must work with various entities to minimize the impact on the environment, culture, commerce, safety, and quality of life near proposed action sites. This subsection does not create or negate any rights of action, affect eminent domain laws, or waive other applicable laws. The Secretary is not required to install specific security measures. The Secretary of Homeland Security is not obligated to install fencing, barriers, or other security measures along the border if they are not deemed effective or if the costs and impacts outweigh the benefits. This is in accordance with the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996. The Secretary of Homeland Security must wait 90 days after submitting the border protection strategy to Congress before starting any construction of fencing, barriers, or other infrastructure along the international land border of the United States. SEC. 6. BORDERLANDS MONITORING AND MITIGATION. The Secretary, in consultation with various agencies, must develop a monitoring and mitigation plan for the ecological impacts of border security infrastructure along US international land borders. The plan includes measures to preserve wildlife habitats, migration corridors, and address invasive species. The mitigation plan for ecological impacts of border security infrastructure along US international land borders includes preserving habitats for species, controlling invasive species, maintaining hydrological functionality, incorporating adaptive management, and protecting cultural and historical resources. The Secretary has the authority to implement this plan on various lands regardless of ownership. The Secretary of Homeland Security can transfer funds to other agencies for conservation activities related to border security infrastructure on various lands regardless of ownership. Activities must be carried out in consultation with the landowner or entity responsible for land management. The Secretary of Homeland Security can transfer funds to other agencies for conservation activities on non-Federal lands and mitigation activities on Federal lands. Funds transferred are exempt from reprogramming requirements, and donations can be accepted for developing and implementing the mitigation plan. The Secretary of Homeland Security can accept donations for developing and implementing a mitigation plan required for border security infrastructure. Appropriated funds can also be used for this purpose.
